question_user: Can the new Commission finish matters started by the Former Commission before 1 Oct 2016?
question_variants: Can PDPC complete work begun by the old Commission?
Can ongoing cases from before 2016 continue under the new Commission?
gold_answer_short: Yes. The new Commission may carry on and complete any matter started by or for the Former Commission.
gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.67(2), where anything was started by or on behalf of the Former Commission before 1 October 2016, the current Commission may carry on and complete that matter on or after that date.

question_user: Are decisions made by the Former Commission before 1 Oct 2016 still valid?
question_variants: Do old PDPC approvals still stand?
Are guidelines issued by the old Commission recognised?
gold_answer_short: Yes. They remain valid as if made by the current Commission, unless inconsistent with the amended Act.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.67(3) states that any approval, authorisation, decision, direction, exemption, guideline or notice given by the Former Commission before 1 October 2016 remains valid and is deemed to have been made by the Commission, to the extent it is not inconsistent with the amended Act.

question_user: If an application to the Former Commission was still pending on 1 Oct 2016, what happens to it?
question_variants: What happens to PDPC applications filed before 2016?
Do pending PDPA cases transfer to the new Commission?
gold_answer_short: It is treated as an application made to the current Commission, unless inconsistent with the amended Act.
gold_answer_extended: According to PDPA s.67(4), any pending application made to the Former Commission before 1 October 2016 is deemed to be made to the current Commission under the Act, to the extent consistent with amendments made by the IMDA Act 2016.

question_user: What happens to appeals filed before 1 Oct 2016 against the Former Commission’s decisions?
question_variants: Do old PDPA appeals continue?
Who handles appeals lodged before 2016?
gold_answer_short: They are deemed to be appeals against decisions of the current Commission.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.67(5) provides that any appeal made before 1 October 2016 under Part 8 is deemed to be an appeal in respect of a direction or decision of the new Commission.

question_user: Do certificates signed by the Chairman of the Former Commission remain valid?
question_variants: Are old PDPC certificates still recognised?
Does the Chief Executive now take over earlier certificates?
gold_answer_short: Yes. They remain valid and are deemed to have been signed by the Chief Executive of the Authority.
gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.67(6), any authorisation, certificate, or document signed by the Former Commission’s Chairman before 1 October 2016 remains valid and is deemed to have been made or signed by the Chief Executive of the Authority.

question_user: What does PDPA s.67(7) state?
question_variants: Is s.67(7) still active?
What does subsection (7) cover?
gold_answer_short: It has been omitted as spent.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.67(7) is marked '[Omitted as spent]', meaning its transitional purpose has expired and it no longer applies.

question_user: Does section 67 override the Interpretation Act’s general savings provisions?
question_variants: Does s.67 affect the Interpretation Act?
Are Interpretation Act protections still valid?
gold_answer_short: No. Section 67 does not affect the operation of section 16 of the Interpretation Act.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.67(8) explicitly states that this section does not affect section 16 of the Interpretation Act 1965, which contains general saving provisions.

question_user: Who is referred to as the ‘Former Commission’ in sections 67 and 68?
question_variants: What does Former Commission mean?
Which body is the Former Commission?
gold_answer_short: The Personal Data Protection Commission established under s.5(1) as in force immediately before 1 October 2016.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.67(9) defines 'Former Commission' as the Personal Data Protection Commission established by section 5(1) as it stood immediately before 1 October 2016.

question_user: Is the Former Commission still in existence?
question_variants: Does the old PDPC still exist?
Was the Former Commission abolished?
gold_answer_short: No. The Former Commission is dissolved.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.68(1) states that the Former Commission is dissolved, confirming that it no longer exists after 1 October 2016.

question_user: Who does the term 'Former Commission' refer to in section 68?
question_variants: What does Former Commission mean in the dissolution section?
Is the definition of Former Commission reused from s.67?
gold_answer_short: It has the meaning given by section 67(9).
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.68(2) provides that in that section, 'Former Commission' carries the same meaning as defined in s.67(9).

question_user: Can the new Commission change or revoke a decision made by the Former Commission?
question_variants: Can PDPC overturn past decisions from before 2016?
Are earlier rulings revisable?
gold_answer_short: Yes, provided it does so under its powers and where the previous decision is not inconsistent with the amended Act.
gold_answer_extended: While PDPA s.67(3) preserves former decisions to the extent they’re consistent with the amended Act, the current Commission may exercise its authority to vary or revoke them as permitted under current law.

question_user: Are pending investigations before 1 Oct 2016 still valid under the new PDPC?
question_variants: Do old investigations continue under new Commission?
Can PDPC continue inquiries begun by the Former Commission?
gold_answer_short: Yes. The new Commission may carry on and complete them.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.67(2) allows the current Commission to carry on and complete any matter, such as investigations, started by the Former Commission before 1 October 2016.

question_user: If an appeal was ongoing before 1 Oct 2016, does it have to restart under the new PDPC?
question_variants: Do appellants need to refile after 2016 transition?
Are earlier appeals voided?
gold_answer_short: No. They continue as appeals against decisions of the new Commission.
gold_answer_extended: According to PDPA s.67(5), appeals made before 1 October 2016 under Part 8 are deemed to continue as appeals against decisions of the new Commission, without restarting.

question_user: Who signs certificates now that the Former Commission’s Chairman role no longer exists?
question_variants: Who replaces the Former Chairman for certifications?
Who signs authorisations now?
gold_answer_short: The Chief Executive of the Authority.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.67(6) provides that any certificate or document previously signed by the Chairman of the Former Commission is now deemed signed by the Chief Executive of the Authority.

question_user: Can section 67 affect other laws’ general savings of acts done before repeal?
question_variants: Does PDPA override Interpretation Act section 16?
Are general savings under Interpretation Act still intact?
gold_answer_short: No. Section 67 expressly preserves section 16 of the Interpretation Act.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.67(8) clarifies that its transitional provisions do not displace the operation of s.16 of the Interpretation Act 1965, which governs continuing validity of prior acts under repealed laws.

question_user: What is the significance of the transitional provisions in section 67?
question_variants: Why does PDPA include saving provisions?
What do transitional clauses in s.67 achieve?
gold_answer_short: They ensure continuity by preserving actions, decisions, and applications of the Former Commission.
gold_answer_extended: Sections 67(1)–(6) of the PDPA maintain continuity through the 2016 institutional change, validating acts and pending matters of the Former Commission as if made or handled by the new Commission.

question_user: What does section 68(1) mean for the Former Commission’s legal existence?
question_variants: What is the effect of dissolution under s.68?
Does s.68 terminate the old PDPC’s authority?
gold_answer_short: It means the Former Commission ceased to exist legally.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.68(1) declares that the Former Commission is dissolved, ending its corporate and administrative existence upon the 2016 transition.

question_user: If the Former Commission was dissolved, who took over its functions?
question_variants: Which body replaced the old PDPC?
Who now performs the Former Commission’s duties?
gold_answer_short: The current Commission established under the amended Act took over its functions.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA ss.67–68 collectively indicate that after the dissolution of the Former Commission, its functions, powers, and duties were assumed by the new Commission established under the amended Act.

question_user: Can an approval issued before 1 Oct 2016 still be used if inconsistent with the amended PDPA?
question_variants: Are inconsistent old approvals still valid?
What happens if old decisions conflict with new law?
gold_answer_short: No. It remains valid only to the extent it is not inconsistent with the amended Act.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.67(3) limits the continued validity of approvals or decisions made by the Former Commission to those consistent with the PDPA as amended by the IMDA Act 2016.

question_user: Does section 68 create any new powers or offences?
question_variants: Does dissolution add new enforcement powers?
Are new offences created by s.68?
gold_answer_short: No. It only dissolves the Former Commission and defines the term used.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.68 simply provides for the dissolution of the Former Commission and defines 'Former Commission' by reference to s.67(9). It does not create new powers or offences.

question_user: If an act by the Former Commission conflicts with new provisions, is it automatically void?
question_variants: What happens to inconsistent old directions?
Are earlier rulings cancelled if inconsistent?
gold_answer_short: Yes. Earlier acts only remain valid to the extent they are not inconsistent with the amended Act.
gold_answer_extended: Under PDPA s.67(3), prior decisions or directions from the Former Commission are deemed valid as if made by the current Commission only insofar as they do not conflict with the PDPA as amended.

question_user: What is meant by 'Former Commission' in the context of the PDPA’s dissolution clauses?
question_variants: What does Former Commission refer to under s.68?
Who was the Former Commission before dissolution?
gold_answer_short: It refers to the Personal Data Protection Commission established under s.5(1) before 1 October 2016.
gold_answer_extended: Both PDPA ss.67(9) and 68(2) define the Former Commission as the Commission constituted under s.5(1) immediately before 1 October 2016, which was later dissolved under s.68(1).

question_user: Does PDPA s.67(2) allow the new Commission to reopen closed matters of the Former Commission?
question_variants: Can PDPC revisit cases finished before 2016?
Does continuation include reopening completed matters?
gold_answer_short: No. It only allows carrying on and completing matters already started, not reopening completed ones.
gold_answer_extended: PDPA s.67(2) authorises the new Commission to carry on and complete ongoing matters of the Former Commission, but not to reopen matters already concluded before 1 October 2016.

question_user: Is the term ‘Former Commission’ used elsewhere in the PDPA beyond sections 67 and 68?
question_variants: Where else does Former Commission appear?
Is Former Commission referenced outside transitional parts?
gold_answer_short: The excerpt does not indicate other sections; cannot determine.
gold_answer_extended: From the provided text, 'Former Commission' appears only in ss.67 and 68. Whether it appears elsewhere cannot be confirmed without the full Act.
abstain_gold_message: The excerpt does not show whether the term appears beyond ss.67 and 68.
ask_for_clarification_suggestions: Check the full PDPA text for other references to 'Former Commission'.
